awd_titl_txt: Measurement of the Higgs Sector Through Decays to B-quarks
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support to a Stony Brook University group working on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC machine and ATLAS, a large particle detector facility, were built as basic science tools using funds from NSF and other agencies around the world. One of their primary objectives was to find the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the existence of, and forces between, known particles forming the matter in the universe. This effort has been successful. The next step in the experiments is to study the properties and characteristics of this newly discovered particle as a laboratory to see if it behaves as the SM predicts or if there are deviations suggesting evidence for new physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) that might, for instance, account for the presence of the mysterious "Dark Matter" that makes up so much of the mass of the universe. The LHC is currently in the midst of Run 2, at almost twice the energy explored earlier and with significantly increased event samples. It is possible that evidence for BSM physics could emerge at this higher energy and with the higher event statistics from the current run and by means of further upgrades of the LHC and ATLAS to follow.

Analytically, to facilitate a detailed study of the Higgs Boson and search for other new states of matter, the Stony Brook group will be studying final states containing b-quark jets, with focus on advancing the identification of b-jets with ever high transverse momentum.  On the technical side, the group is engaged in the Phase II upgrade of the ATLAS inner tracker, called the ITK, for the high luminosity LHC.  The work concentrates on two areas:  simulation studies of the b-tagging performance for high transverse momentum jets with the upgraded detector, and development of the data acquisition system for the ITK strip detector. 

Through this work, the Stony Brook group's broader impacts efforts include development of state-of-the-art software and computing tools, and the direct participation of undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers in cutting edge scientific research and instrumentation development.  Such efforts help to lay the groundwork for future innovations in other areas, and for general economic development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We lead research using data from the Large Hadron Collider recorded with the ATLAS experiment. The research primarily addresses questions about the Higgs Boson: How does it interact with known particles? Do its production or decay properties imply the existance of hypothetical particles which not part of our standard theory? The Higgs Boson is interesting for many reasons, and among them are three in particular which motivate our research: (1) the Higgs Boson provides the means for all particles to have mass, (2) it is the only fundamental particle without spin and (3) it is the most recently discovered fundamental particle leaving room for unexpected results in measurements of its properties.

When this award started, it was not conclusively proven yet whether the Higgs Boson would couple directly with fermions. We co-led the ATLAS search for Higgs Boson decays to b-quarks, which resulted in the first 5-sigma observation of Higgs to b-quarks decays in Summer 2018. With this result, we confirmed that the Higgs mechanism provides masses to both bosons and fermions. We also started to explore more subtle deviations that may happen when considering collisions at especially high energy. This corresponds to exploring smaller scales, for example considering the hypothesis that the Higgs Boson might be composite, i.e. composed by other particles, rather than being itself elementary. We extended current analyses techniques to directly probe such scenarios, and we produced several publications with these results, focused both on Higgs Boson decays to tau leptons and b-quark jets. We were also responsible for co-coordinating all ATLAS Higgs Boson measurements between 2018 and 2020. Thus far our measurements are in agreement with theory predictions, but with the increasing data sets available over the coming decade, the precision of these tests will significantly improve and allow ever more incisive tests. 

We also spearheaded several technical tools and innovative techniques in the domains of identifying b-quark jets and tau-leptons, and we documented such techniques in public notes or papers, at the same time making them available to a large class of physics analyses performed within ATLAS. We also worked on developing the readout for the ITK strip detector that will become part of the Tracker when the ATLAS detector will be upgraded for the High Luminosity phase of the LHC.

As part of our research program, we mentored and trained Physics graduate and undergraduate students during summers and as part of academic year research. We organized public talks and public events as side-programs to several international conferences we held at Stony Brook/Simons Center for Geometry and Physics in order to communicate the science we do to the wider public and to students from local schools.
